captions.text:
Are you ready to get silly? Cuz I'm
ready to get silly.
It doesn't get
sillier than this (laugh).
This is the manliest thing I've ever done in my life.
Driver's cars don't get much better than these two:
the Jaguar F-Type Coupe R and Porsche 911 50th anniversary edition

are about us fantastic as their names
are long. Both have carbon ceramic brakes,

active dampers, active differentials, and
both are rear-drive.

Both are also intent on making the
driving experience

enjoyable and rewarding, which one does
it best?

The two cars are similar in length and
height though the Jag is nearly

three inches wider. With 550 horsepower
from its supercharged

5 liter V8 the Coupe R is the most
powerful production Jag ever.

But that almost doesn't matter
because just look at it.

The Coupe is one of those cars that could
pass on design alone

you catch yourself just staring at it. It
features a masterful collection of design traits:
a long nose, the slope greenhouse, those wide haunches,

and how the quad exhaust pipes exit at
the bumper tilted just slightly up.

The proportions are simply gorgeous it's
a design that evokes

images of all great classical sports cars.
You could confuse it with something
Italian & in the best way possible. The F-Type is simply a knockout in terms of design.
It's a stunningly beautiful car.

Fortunately the aesthetic benefits of
having a roof match the improvements it
brings to the chassis

namely a dramatic increase in torsional
rigidity.
Though it starts at around $100,000 this one totals $117,475

mostly due to the inclusion of enormous
15.7 inch front
and 14.8 inch rear carbon ceramic brakes,

and the 20 inch wheels required to fit. A
package that cost $12,000.
A standard 911 Carerra S
also starts at around $100,000 but this
50th anniversary edition increases the base price
another $20,000. It's essentially a Carerra S with the
4S body making it 1.7 inches wider in the rear.

It also adds the modernized Fuchs wheels,
houndstooth seats, and a power kit

which includes new heads, cams, intake
system

radiator exhaust, ECU, and a
power increase
to 430 horse total price $151,620.
You might say it's just another 911,

but in person in the parking lot it
looks absolutely fantastic. It doesn't

evoke the same slack-jawed stares as the
F-Type,

but it does catch and hold your eyes for
a long time.
Launching these cars is easy and they were remarkably consistent in our testing.
In the Jag you activate dynamic mode and put the traction control in Sport

then lay into the throttle gradual but not
aggressively. Without much tire spin
the Jag reaches sixty in 3.6 seconds
and the quarter mile in 11.88 at 102.3 miles an hour.

That isn't the quickest we've seen from
an F-Type, but it's enough to be
beat Porsche in a drag race.
In the 911 you hit the Sport plus button and slam both pedals,

release the brake, and it does sixty in
3.9 seconds.
In the quarter mile in 12.2 at 115.4 miles an hour.

While they pass the quarter about a half
second apart there's nearly
a 7 mile an hour difference in trap speed. The Jag's got the power,
but it also weighs 560 pounds more bringing its power to weight advantage
down to 0.7 pounds per horsepower.
Both cars have Pirelli P-Zeros and ceramic brakes,

but the Porsche narrowly edges out the
Jag's best breaking performance by

5 feet producing a best stop from 60
miles an hour
in 101 feet.
Around great the figure-8 the 911 and the Jag put down lap times within a tenth of each other.

Well despite the power deficiency the
Porsche pulls
1g average on the skid pad. The Jag just 0.94.

Whatever the 911 loses on the
street as the Jaguar accelerates ahead
it makes up for in the corners. The Coupe R turns in nicely,

but defaults to understeer as you ask more
from the chassis. The instant you step on
throttle

it transitions to oversteer. It feels
like the car set up the power slide and
that's fun when you're horsing around but requires extra concentration on the throttle

during corner exit we're trying to get
a lap time. The Porsche dials into
corners

beautifully and offers an astounding
traction on exit.

Where the Jag needs mindful throttle
application the Porsche could be driven
with the foot to the floor.
This thing is so muscular and brawny such
a brawler of a car. It's like a British corvette.
This is just clobbering the road like you're just obliterating things in your path.
And all of the world is going to
know that you're doing that because of how loud this thing is.
When I first started driving this thing hard on the road the first thing I wanted
was to tear my shirt open and flex my chest
and admire all the new chest hair that had just been grown.
We of course have an automatic eight-speed transmission,
and on the road the way I've been driving I haven't really noticed any downsides
between this

and Porsche's PDK. When you're shifting
manually it's responsive,
its fast,
it matches red, it's a really nicely done
transmission. Where I think the difference in driving philosophy is the rear end

this thing seems to be set up in a way
to make you think it's going to oversteer
all the time.

And as we found out at the test track that's
exactly what you want it wants to do when
you're on power,

but it does so in a very controllable
way so it's not
frightening you're just
aware of it more than you are the 911.

I wish this car was lighter and I wish
it was a bit smaller
and those I think would pay dividends
in the way this thing handles.
this car doesn't lie about its weight

you're aware it doesn't shrink around you it
pretty much stays
feeling big and heavy when you

drive it fast. It feels a bit tighter in
here because
the dash is a lot taller, the windshield's rigged

it's a bit narrower, and you feel like
it's all because there's this giant
5 liter supercharged V8 sitting right here.
The first thing you notice when you hop in the 911
this interior feels more open like you can see more things.
that's because you don't have a big 5 liter V8 with a supercharger
on top of it blocking your view. What you have is a big open windshield
and a hood that swoops down all you can really see is where the

headlights are at the body around there.
And that
is one of the reasons why
driving this car is so sweet.

Now the 2 this and the Jaguar are very
similar

in size this is a bit lighter than the
Jaguar,

but this manages to feel smaller and
lighter the faster you drive it.
This car operates as one

solid piece of machine it's not a bunch of
parts
working independently of each other that you have to mine individually.
It refuses none of your requests
it sort of engages you and

makes you want to go faster and harder.
You think in some corners I might have to
lift off here
no you can just go flat and steer through it and the car has the grip,

and the balance to get you through
without issue. This is

wonderful, wonderful, wonderful, wonderful
driving car.
You also notice that the exhaust is
a lot quieter.
It doesn't have the ferociousness

of that Jaguar's exhaust. It has a bit
more soul than the Jaguar

the Jags all heavy metal and that's cool
that's,

they're both good in different ways, but
you could almost read into the
personality
of each car through the way their exhaust's sound.

These cars are nothing short of
exceptional both thrilling
and engaging
they make you laugh, they make you happy, driving either one will
make your day. Driving both hard on the same day

is the kinda stuff we live for. The
Jaguar looks so gorgeous
and it has hugely enjoyable character. What it lacks in absolute live performance

it makes up for with sheer theatrics. It
makes you smile
endlessly. The Porsche too
looks fantastic and it too is fun to drive even when you're just getting
groceries.

But the 911 has a higher upper limit
that makes it so rewarding to push hard.
It keeps asking you for more and it keeps meeting and then

exceeding your expectations for that
reason
the 911 50th anniversary edition wins this Head2Head.

title: 2015 Jaguar F-Type Coupe R vs 2014 Porsche 911 50th Anniversary Edition - Head 2 Head Ep. 55
